title.children: Dozens evicted from their homes as Sydney council targets 'sub-standard' boarding houses

image.altText: Promo image of a line chart showing housing costs broken down by income.

items.synopsis: Housing costs are at record highs, and we can show you who is bearing the brunt of the crisis.

title.children: Where you sit on this chart determines your level of housing stress

image.altText: A mother and father holding their young daughter between them, smiling. They are standing on an apartment balcony.

items.synopsis: Medium- and high-density development in established suburbs is being spruiked as the solution to Australia's housing crisis. But there are still some risks.

title.children: Sean and Jane paid $720,000 for an apartment with no car parks and shared laundry. It was their path out of renting

image.altText: A man looks on, waving his arms

items.synopsis: Spain's beleaguered football federation sacks the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia.

items.synopsis: Trove of confidential documents shed light on claims by energy giant that throwing a lifeline to an ageing coal plant could be 'low cost' for taxpayers.

title.children: 'Low cost' or 'bottomless pit'? Secret documents detail failed efforts to rescue huge coal plant

image.altText: Vanessa Hudson, the incoming Qantas CEO, with model plane in foreground showing Flying Kangaroo

items.synopsis: With Alan Joyce announcing his abrupt departure from Qantas two months ahead of schedule, Vanessa Hudson is now in control of an airline with a reputation problem — and disgruntled customers say it will be tough to win them back.

title.children: New Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson faces an uphill battle to restore the public's faith as Alan Joyce departs

image.altText: Construction site for Sydney's new metro line with sign saying we're building tomorrow's Sydney

items.synopsis: Some Sydney Metro contractors are running consulting companies which have won multi-million contracts with the same government agency, a parliamentary inquiry hears.

title.children: Sydney Metro questioned over 'unusual' use of consultants who can earn more than department secretaries

image.altText: Albanese stands speaking to media from a courtyard.

items.synopsis: The PM will use a speech to the ASEAN summit on Wednesday to release the government's South-East Asian Economic Strategy, a blueprint aimed at driving trade and investment north into the region.

title.children: Anthony Albanese starts summit season talking trade ties and regional security, with China in mind

image.altText: young girl on bus.

items.synopsis: From war-torn hills and valleys, to the sheep and wheat paddocks of remote Australia, the Karen people are determined to pass down their language and traditions to the next generation.

title.children: Karen refugees keep their culture alive in rural Australia after fleeing war in Myanmar

image.altText: A close up of Enrique at a rally outside wearing black sunglasses and a black cap that says The War.

items.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Former Proud Boys leader jailed for 22 years over January 6. The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The White House has warned that North Korea will "pay a price" if it sells weapons to Russia for its war in Ukraine. It comes as Kim Jong Un and Vladimir Putin are expected to hold talks on the issue. Sanctions-hit Russia is reportedly eager to secure more military supplies from its ally to bolster its forces as Kyiv pushes a highly scrutinised counteroffensive to take back its territory. US President Joe Biden's national security advisor Jake Sullivan says Pyongyang and Moscow are eyeing "leader-level discussions, perhaps even in person" on Russia's arms needs. Sullivan says Russia could use weapons from North Korea to attack food supplies and heating infrastructure heading into winter to "try to conquer territory that belongs to another sovereign nation". "This is not going to reflect well on North Korea and they will pay a price for this in the international community," he says. "[It] says a lot that Russia is having to turn to a country like North Korea." "We have continued to squeeze Russia's defence industrial base," he says, and Moscow is now "looking to whatever source they can find" for goods like ammunition .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US says North Korea will pay 'price' if it sells arms to Russia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by North American correspondent Barbara Miller The former chairman of the far-right Proud Boys group Enrique Tarrio has been sentenced to 22 years' prison for his role in the events of January 6. Dressed in an orange jumpsuit, the 39 year-old was in court in Washington, DC to hear the sentence, the longest handed down so far in the criminal cases resulting from January 6. Tarrio addressed the court ahead of sentencing, describing what happened on January 6 as "national embarrassment" and apologised to members of Congress, the police officers who defended the Capitol and the citizens of Washington, DC. The defendant pleaded with the judge to show him mercy and broke down when talking of his family, saying he had failed them. The prosecution argued Tarrio organised street violence on a national scale, bringing together the group that entered the Capitol, instructing and leading them. In handing down the sentence Judge Timothy Kelly said what happened on January 6 damaged a precious American tradition of the peaceful transfer of power and it was going to take time to fix it.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BREAKING: Former Proud Boys leader sentenced to 22 years over January 6

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Spain's beleaguered football federation has sacked the coach of its national women's team, Jorge Vilda, less than three weeks after he oversaw its World Cup triumph in Australia. In a statement, the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) did not give a reason for its decision. Last year, 15 players announced they would no longer represent the national team and Vilda unless "significant" concerns were addressed. While three of them made themselves available for the World Cup, the majority remained on the sidelines. Vilda had publicly supported RFEF president Luis Rubiales, who has been widely criticised since aggressively kissing player Jenni Hermoso on the mouth after Spain became world champions. You can continue reading this story using the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach

featuredLink.title: Spain sacks World Cup-winning women's coach as post-tournament chaos continues

props.alt: A close up of Jorge at a press conference.

title.children: With his last interest rates decision made, will Philip Lowe move to a private bank?
